caption_text: As evident from Fig. 1, stabilization for higher times (say for three hours and more) drastically reduces the strength of the fibers. Of course, the extent of the decrease with time will depend on the temperature of stabilization, etc. In addition to the incorporation in the long chain structure of the fiber, oxygen also makes surface chemical complexes on the fibers.

caption_text: During pyrolysis, though the fiber and matrix both undergo chemical reactions with evolution of byproducts and get carbonized, the fiber matrix bond- ing is maintained and both fibers and matrix are easily distinguishable (Fig. 6). In no case was coalesc- ence of the two phases observed. Previous studies by the author [6] on carboniza- tion of carbon fiber reinforced thermosetting resin composites has shown that strong fiber/matrix bond- ing leads to excessive shrinkage cracks in the matrix during carbonization.
raw_window: During pyrolysis, though the fiber and matrix both undergo chemical reactions with evolution of byproducts and get carbonized, the fiber matrix bond- ing is maintained and both fibers and matrix are easily distinguishable (Fig. 6).
In no case was coalesc- ence of the two phases observed.

Previous studies by the author [6] on carboniza- tion of carbon fiber reinforced thermosetting resin composites has shown that strong fiber/matrix bond- ing leads to excessive shrinkage cracks in the matrix during carbonization.

caption_text: Furthermore, the development of a distinct anisotropy at the fiber matrix interface is observed (Fig. 6), as also reported for carbonized composites made with carbon fibers [4,6]. Comparison of the observations made with the two carbonized composites exhibited a higher extent of this anisotropy in composites made with oxidised PAN fibers (Fig. 6 (a)) as compared to in those made with carbon fibers (Fig. 6(b)). Optical microscopic observations of the carbonized compos- ites showed that not only the matrix but the fibers also exhibit anisotropy in the structure.
raw_window: Furthermore, the development of a distinct anisotropy at the fiber matrix interface is observed (Fig. 6), as also reported for carbonized composites made with carbon fibers [4,6].

Comparison of the observations made with the two carbonized composites exhibited a higher extent of this anisotropy in composites made with oxidised PAN fibers (Fig. 6 (a)) as compared to in those made with carbon fibers (Fig. 6(b)).
Optical microscopic observations of the carbonized compos- ites showed that not only the matrix but the fibers also exhibit anisotropy in the structure.

caption_text: On heat treatment of the composites to 2800°C, the anisotropic structure in matrix gets enhanced (Fig. 7(a)). Even the bulk carbon matrix in the interfiber tow region is observed to have developed good anisotropic structure (Fig. 7(b)) 3.3.2 Scanning electron microscopic observa- tions Cross-sections of the carbonized as well as graphitized composites were also viewed under a JEOL Scanning Electron Microscope. Figure 8 shows the SEM micrographs of carbonized composites.
raw_window: On heat treatment of the composites to 2800°C, the anisotropic structure in matrix gets enhanced (Fig. 7(a)).

Even the bulk carbon matrix in the interfiber tow region is observed to have developed good anisotropic structure (Fig. 7(b)) 3.3.2 Scanning electron microscopic observa- tions Cross-sections of the carbonized as well as graphitized composites were also viewed under a JEOL Scanning Electron Microscope.
Figure 8 shows the SEM micrographs of carbonized composites.

caption_text: Distinct fibers and matrix are identifiable in Fig. 8(b). Striations origi- nating from the fibers and extending to the matrix represent the initiation of anisotropic structure devel- opment in the carbon matrix. The anisotropic struc- ture in the matrix becomes quite predominant in graphitised composites.
